Guide students through a reading of By the Light of the Moon.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Personal Response
Have students write about what it would be like to have a feast with their friends.
Before writing, allow students to orally share with a partner what they want to write.
Prompt them to look back at the story for support in writing.

Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that identifies the animals in the story. (mice)
What does the young mouse observe about the moon? Find the sentence that answers the question.
The young mice want to fly to the moon and bring back cheese for their friends. What does this tell you about them?
If you had the chance to fly to the moon, would you go? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

Find the times of day when coyotes are most active. (sunrise, sunset)
When do coyote pups have the opportunity to leave their den? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How do mother and father coyotes help to raise their pups? Explain.
Have you ever seen a coyote? What was it doing? If not, then what wild animals have you seen in your area?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

to review syllable types with students.
Review that words are made up of syllables and that each syllable has one vowel sound.
Explain that students can use what they know about syllables and spelling patterns to read longer words.
Model identifying the syllable types within each word and dividing it into syllables. Then have students blend the syllables to read the word.
Closed syllables end in a consonant and usually have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants:
Open syllables end in a vowel and generally have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before the consonant and blend the word with a long vowel sound:
. If the word doesnt sound like a real word, divide it after the vowel and blend with a short vowel sound:
Vowel team syllables have two or more letters that stand for one vowel sound. The vowel team stays together in the same syllable:
Have students use the following words to identify and read the syllables and then blend the syllables to read the words:

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during wordbuilding exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
/ square. Add a square to show me
Students should add a different color square after the purple /
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /

Model identifying the syllable types within each word and dividing it into syllables. Then have students blend the syllables to read the word.
Closed syllables end in a consonant and usually have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants:
Open syllables end in a vowel and generally have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before the consonant and blend the word with a long vowel sound:
. If the word does not sound like a real word, divide it after the vowel and blend with a short vowel sound:
Vowel team syllables have two or more letters that stand for one vowel sound. The vowel team stays together in the same syllable:

Closed syllables end in a consonant and usually have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants:
Open syllables end in a vowel and generally have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before the consonant and blend the word with a long vowel sound:
. If the word doesnt sound like a real word, divide it after the vowel and blend with a short vowel sound:
Vowel team syllables have two or more letters that stand for one vowel sound. The vowel team stays together in the same syllable:

Guide students through a reading of Ocean Zones.

Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Model identifying the syllable types within each word and dividing it into syllables. Then have students blend the syllables to read the word.
Closed syllables end in a consonant and usually have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants:
Open syllables end in a vowel and generally have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before the consonant and blend the word with a long vowel sound:
. If the word does not sound like a real word, divide it after the vowel and blend with a short vowel sound:
Vowel team syllables have two or more letters that stand for one vowel sound. The vowel team stays together in the same syllable:
